titlestmt.titleproper: Ford Foundation records, Staff Subject Files, Jon Funabiki
A Guide to the Ford Foundation records, Staff Subject Files, Jon Funabiki FA1447
titlestmt.author: Katie Martin

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2022-05-01 00:47:03 -0400.

did.unittitle: Ford Foundation records, Staff Subject Files, Jon Funabiki

physdesc.extent: 61 boxes - 59 letter document containers, 1 legal document container, and 1 [19"x15"] photo storage box

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Jon Funabiki joined the Ford Foundation in 1995. He served as Deputy Director of the Media, Arts, and Culture Unit within the Knowledge, Creativity and Freedom Program. While at the Ford Foundation, he prioritized promoting ethics, credibility and diversity in journalism, strengthening media criticism, and promoting freedom of expression.

Jon Funabiki is a graduate of San Francisco State University. Prior to joining the Foundation, he was founding director of San Francisco State University's Center for Integration and Improvement of Journalism. He also directed News Watch: A critical look at coverage of people of color and Project Zinger, an annual analysis of coverage of Asian Pacific Americans, sponsored by the Asian American Journalists Association. Funabiki is a former reporter and editor with The San Diego Union, where he specialized in US-Asia political and economic affairs.
Funabiki is an emeritus professor in journalism at San Francisco State University.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The collection contains Jon Funabiki's office files from the Media, Arts and Culture (MAC) Unit with the Knowledge, Creativity and Freedom (KCF) Program, including grant records, grant-related materials such as RGAs, reports, article clippings, handwritten notes, grantees annual reports, financial statements, correspondence, office files, and meeting materials.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Open for research with select materials restricted as noted. Brittle or damaged items are available at the discretion of RAC. Researchers interested in accessing digital media (floppy disks, CDs, DVDs, etc.) in this collection must use an access surrogate. The original items may not be accessed because of preservation concerns. To request an access surrogate be made, or if you are unsure if there is an access surrogate, please contact an archivist.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: This material was transferred to RAC in 2018 and 2019 by the Ford Foundation and ingested by RAC as Accessions 2018:039, 2019:117, and 2019:138.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: This collection contains two series and two subseries:
Series 1. Media, Arts, and Culture Grant Materials, 1992-2007
Series 2: Media, Arts, and Culture (MAC) Administrative Office Files, Meetings, and Reports, 1990-2007

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: Ford Foundation has title, copyright and literary rights in the collection, in so far as it holds them.

The Rockefeller Archive Center has authority to grant permission to cite and publish material from the collection. Permission to publish extensive excerpts, or material in its entirety, will be referred to the Ford Foundation.
